text: Ok perfect thanks Harun
So if it’s clear for me :

This workflow should work :

• A lead using a personal address email submit a landing page
• The contact is created with the personal address email
• We also add a professional email on a form as a field
• We create manually an account on our system generating a SSO token
• I can ask my SSO provider to change the token and use the personal email for HubSpot in order to match the contact ?
•  The contact is matched and have access to my private content

I’m just questioning about that :

• I can ask my SSO provider to change the token and use the personal email for HubSpot in order to match the contact ?
----

If you have the answer, you save my life :slightly_smiling_face:
HubSpot has <https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/account/can-i-use-single-sign-on-sso-with-HubSpot#instructions-for-specific-identity-providers|instructions here for a few Identity providers>.
To the best of my knowledge you need to be able to access and update the DNS records, otherwise anyone could point any domain wherever they want.
Thanks, it’s a custom development using AWS i’ll ask them
sure if it is custom, then they should be able to accommodate your request to include email in the JWT

Hi All!
i am looking for a some technical assistance please.
i am looking to find a way to create a webpage or a landing page that i will be redirecting to from another page with a post request and get something from one of the http headers.

ill give a more specific example.
lets say that i want to have some registration form. this form will be accessed only via other websites. and i want to take the referrer header from the HTTP request and automatically fill it in one of the fields

Hi, I am with a company called nooks and we provided classified space as a service for gov and industry. We use HubSpot for our sales outreach and organization. I have been toying with the idea of having an app developed for our client's use and was wondering said app could work with and access the information we have within HubSpot. Would anyone in the app development realm within HubSpot be willing to have a phone call with me to discuss possibilities?
Yes, you can, by using their API's. You can take a look at this article for more information : <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/overview>

hi! we’re looking at implementing login with HubSpot, we’ve seen this on a few sites but all I can find in the docs is <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/working-with-oauth|oauth for data connectivity> with HubSpot which doesn’t seem to return a user email, which would be a blocker for offering HubSpot as an oauth login method. are there other docs around using HubSpot oauth for login?

I would say it depends a bit on the content, but either route can work. The most obvious element would be the fact that a landing page would have a lot more flexibility in the page content than a blog post would... as the entire landing page would have drag-n-drop content with access to all of the modules in your theme. Then a blog post would be limited to the blog post template structure.

Generally, a landing page would be used and include the form with a redirect to the gated content after form submission. Something I've also done within a blog though is a custom module in the blog post template that covers all but the start of the blog post and requires a form to be filled out to view the post. Then after submitting, update a property in the contact that is checked by this module so when that user comes back, they won't have to fill out the form again. That works well for gating blog content as a whole... but if you are gating one-off content items, I'd just roll with landing pages.
If you're talking about logging in to the HubSpot site to access private content, you don't need any API docs. You just need the membership functionality that comes with CMS Enterprise.
thanks for the prompt reply <@U0397BZRK6G>, is there a fundamental difference between a website page and landing page? or mainly the gated content is the difference?
no I’m talking about offering login with HubSpot, for example: <https://apps.chilipiper.com/login.html>
The only difference between a website page and a landing page is where you find it inside of the HubSpot admin. :)
